text: fifty years ago the guggenheim museum
designed by frank lloyd wright opened in
new york city the guggenheim museum was
an aggressive act Frank Lloyd Wright
hated cities his spiraling museum was in
a way an attack against the Manhattan
street grid the interior of the museum
as well has its own kinds of rigidity
Wright likened it to the spiral of life
but it also resembled in its own way the
spiraling ramps of a parking garage over
the years Wright's building has become
an artwork as important as many of the
works that have hung on its walls in my
mind the best shows of the Guggenheim
tend to be sculpture shows or
architectural installations
the Frank Gehry show for example
transform spiraling ramps into a big
workshop and the messiness of gary's
models played off the sleekness of the
ramps in a beautiful way the Richard
print show with the body of a car lodged
in a block the center of the rotunda
touching on themes of the open road and
freedom also acted as a beautiful
counterpoint to the fluidity of the
ramps I think it becomes more difficult
when you're trying to break away from a
conventional straightforward narrative
the David Smith show for example where
the sculptures had room to breathe
worked beautifully and that it was a
very straightforward narrative sequence
as you wound your way up the ramps but
in something like the Spanish show where
you had all Greco's and Picasso's and
one painting lined up next to the other
and you couldn't break out of that
narrative you couldn't set up views
through doorways from one room to
another then the building becomes
somewhat rigid now the museum is
celebrating its fiftieth anniversary
with an exhibit of Wright's work many
critics still see his building as
unsympathetic to art too rigid a
difficult place to install art
it is designed of course to be a smooth
surface but over time and just being the
nature of the building there's always a
little bit of flux so nothing's perfect
right died six months before the museum
opened over the last 50 years it's put
on nearly 500 shows and undergone two
rounds of renovation in the case of the
Guggenheim the idea was to experience
art in a completely different way and
that art is a social experience people
come together in this space and then
they can see each other in this space as
a group there's a constant relationship
between your fellow visitors you see on
the ground you see them through the
ramps you see them across the ramps at
50 the Guggenheim remains a radical
model for an art museum
it's rotunda continues to inspire
generations of architects
I think the building probably functions
on both the art and architecture level
it's it's a great piece of architecture
and it's the biggest objects in our
collection and we're very happy with
that for the New York Times this is
Nikolai rusev
